frontmatter.title: Axiom of choice in set theory

mainmatter.p: For every nonempty family \{ A_i \} _{i \in I} of nonempty sets, there exists a function f : I \to \bigcup _{i \in I} A_i such that \forall i \in I. \ f(i) \in A_i.

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Lattices and Order
frontmatter.meta: @book{davey-priestley-book, title = {Introduction to Lattices and Order}, date = {2002}, place = {Cambridge CB2 8BS, UK}, edition = {2}, doi = {10.1017/CBO9780511809088}, isbn = {978-0-521-78451-1}, publisher = {Cambridge University Press}, author = {Davey, Brian A. and Priestley, Hilary A.}, }

block.headline: Proof.
block.p: Assume that ( \mathsf{AC} ) holds and let (D, \sqsubseteq ) be a pointed dcpo. Suppose that every element of D fails to be maximal. This is to say that for every x \in D, the set \{ y \in D \mid x < y \} is nonempty.
This means that the family \{ \{ y \in D \mid y> x \} \} _{x \in D} is nonempty. By ( \mathsf{AC} ), there exists a choice function F : D \to D. This function is clearly inflationary by construction.
By the Pointed Dcpo Fixed Point Theorem II, F must have a least fixed point \mu ( F ) satisfying F( \mu ( F ) ) = \mu ( F ). This contradicts the fact that x < F(x) for every x \in D.
